designation: Mandate for Syria and the Lebanon
french_name: Mandat pour la Syrie et le Liban

document_details.location: UNOG Library; ref.: C.528. M.313. 1922. VI.

purpose: Creation of the State of Syria, Greater Lebanon, Alawite State, Jabal ad-Druze, Hatay State

background.post_WWI: Founded in the aftermath of the First World War and the partitioning of the Ottoman Empire.
background.mandate_system: Intended as a trusteeship with the governing country acting until inhabitants were ready for self-government.

territorial_control.initial_control: British held most of Ottoman Mesopotamia and southern part of Ottoman Syria, French controlled the rest of Ottoman Syria.
territorial_control.mandate_assignment: 29 September 1923 France was assigned the League of Nations mandate of Syria, including present-day Lebanon and Alexandretta.

administrative_structure.hatay_annexation: Hatay State was annexed by Turkey in 1939.

end_of_mandate.circumstances: French troops left Syria and Lebanon after both declared independence during World War II.

significance.mandate_system_difference: Mandate system was supposed to differ from colonialism, with the goal of establishing sovereign states.

leadership.League_of_Nations: Governing body under which the mandate was established

summary: The Mandate for Syria and the Lebanon was a League of Nations mandate established after World War I that included the territories of present-day Syria, Lebanon, and parts of Turkey. The mandate was intended as a temporary trusteeship until the inhabitants were ready for self-government, leading to the creation of several states. The French administered the region through various governments and territories until 1946, when the mandate ended, and Syria and Lebanon declared independence.
